timeline.bodyText: It would be helpful to add a bit more context here around why we're confident in this auth mechanism – a link out to https://cloud.google.com/tasks/docs/creating-appengine-handlers#reading_app_engine_task_request_headers should be sufficient, possibly with a quote: "According to Google documentation, the X-AppEngine-QueueName is set and overridden internally, so it is guaranteed to only be present for requests which originated internally via Cloud Tasks infrastructure.
timeline.author: gjuggler

timeline.bodyText:
We should aim to make this easily extensible for future queues. Instead of a single constant with the current queue name, you could use an ImmutableSet here to store the set of expected queue names:
private static final ImmutableSet VALID_QUEUE_NAMES = ImmutableSet.of("rdrQueueTest");
Then at L43, you'd check for set containment instead of string equality.
That should make it very clear how to extend this interceptor for additional queues.
timeline.author: gjuggler

timeline.bodyText:
There's an interesting information gap here: nothing in workbench.yaml specifies which queue name each cloud task handler is associated with.
I'd suggest adding something to the description of each method that makes this explicit, e.g. for /v1/cloudTask/exportResearcherData, you could add:
description: >
Sends researcher data to the RDR. This is a Cloud Task handler intended to be invoked by tasks in the "rdrQueueTest" queue.
This should help any reader unfamiliar with this feature connect the dots and understand what's going on. I always try to document code / infrastructure with the "smart but new to the team" engineer in mind.
